elements.content: X-ray powder diffraction and magnetic susceptibility measurements show that Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) consists of 2D square nets of Ag2+ ions resulting from the corner-sharing of axially elongated AgN4O2 octahedra and exhibits characteristic 2D antiferromagnetism. Nevertheless, μ+SR measurements indicate that Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) undergoes 3D magnetic ordering below 7.8(3) K.
elements.clean_text: X-ray powder diffraction and magnetic susceptibility measurements show that Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) consists of 2D square nets of Ag2+ ions resulting from the corner-sharing of axially elongated AgN4O2 octahedra and exhibits characteristic 2D antiferromagnetism. Nevertheless, μ+SR measurements indicate that Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) undergoes 3D magnetic ordering below 7.8(3) K.

elements.content: The chemistry of 4d ion Ag2+ (4d9, S = 1/2) differs considerably from that of its 3d analogue Cu2+ (3d9, S = 1/2) in that, contrary to the case of Cu2+, coordination compounds of Ag2+ are generally unstable in solution and in the solid state unless the ion is protected against reduction to Ag+ (4d10, S = 0) by suitable ligands. Numerous two-dimensional (2D) antiferromagnets of Cu2+ ions exist, but there is no proven 2D antiferromagnet of Ag2+ ions. Lewis bases such as pyridine (py), 2,2′-bipyridine (2,2′-bipy), and 1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane are known to stabilize Ag2+ ions in the solid state. Ag(py)4(S2O8) apparently consists of square planar Ag2+ ions surrounded by the nitrogen atoms of four py ligands although it is unclear whether the S2O8 2− anion is also coordinated. A promising candidate for a 2D antiferromagnet of Ag2+ ions is Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) (pyz = pyrazine) reported nearly four decades ago. The magnetic properties of this compound measured above 83 K indicated an antiferromagnetic (AFM) exchange interaction, and its IR spectrum suggested the presence of square-planar Ag2+ cations linked through pyz ligands. In this communication we show that Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) is indeed a 2D antiferromagnet on the basis of the crystal structure determination, magnetic property measurements, and density functional theory (DFT) electronic structure calculations.
elements.clean_text: The chemistry of 4d ion Ag2+ (4d9, S = 1/2) differs considerably from that of its 3d analogue Cu2+ (3d9, S = 1/2) in that, contrary to the case of Cu2+, coordination compounds of Ag2+ are generally unstable in solution and in the solid state unless the ion is protected against reduction to Ag+ (4d10, S = 0) by suitable ligands. Numerous two-dimensional (2D) antiferromagnets of Cu2+ ions exist, but there is no proven 2D antiferromagnet of Ag2+ ions. Lewis bases such as pyridine (py), 2,2'-bipyridine (2,2'-bipy), and 1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane are known to stabilize Ag2+ ions in the solid state. Ag(py)4(S2O8) apparently consists of square planar Ag2+ ions surrounded by the nitrogen atoms of four py ligands although it is unclear whether the S2O8 2- anion is also coordinated. A promising candidate for a 2D antiferromagnet of Ag2+ ions is Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) (pyz = pyrazine) reported nearly four decades ago. The magnetic properties of this compound measured above 83 K indicated an antiferromagnetic (AFM) exchange interaction, and its IR spectrum suggested the presence of square-planar Ag2+ cations linked through pyz ligands. In this communication we show that Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) is indeed a 2D antiferromagnet on the basis of the crystal structure determination, magnetic property measurements, and density functional theory (DFT) electronic structure calculations.

elements.content: Dark red-brown Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) was synthesized in nearly quantitative yield using the procedure described in ref 4. The IR spectrum of the resulting product reproduced the previously reported data. The crystal structure of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) was determined by combining synchrotron X-ray powder diffraction with ab initio methods (see ). The crystal structure of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) differs from the postulated one in that it consists of octahedral AgN4O2 units that are linked by bridging pyz and S2O8 2− to form a three-dimensional (3D) network.
elements.clean_text: Dark red-brown Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) was synthesized in nearly quantitative yield using the procedure described in ref 4. The IR spectrum of the resulting product reproduced the previously reported data. The crystal structure of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) was determined by combining synchrotron X-ray powder diffraction with ab initio methods (see ). The crystal structure of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) differs from the postulated one in that it consists of octahedral AgN4O2 units that are linked by bridging pyz and S2O8 2- to form a three-dimensional (3D) network.

elements.content: Each Ag2+ cation is equatorially coordinated to four N-donor atoms from pyz ligands [Ag−N1a = 2.239(9), Ag−N1b = 2.230(7) (×2), and Ag−N2a = 2.253(9) Å] and two axial O-atoms from the S2O8 2− anion at much longer distances of 2.62(3) Å. Thus, each Ag(pyz)2O2 layer of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) is made up of corner-sharing axially elongated AgN4O2 octahedra. The Ag−N bond distances observed in Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) agree with those found in related systems, e.g., Ag(2,2′-bipy)2(NO3)2 and Ag(L 4)(NO3)2 (L = meso-5,5,7,12,12,14-hexamethyl-1,4,8,11-tetra-azacyclo-tetradecane). Another Ag2+ compound, (1,4,7,10,13,16-hexathiacyclooctadecane)silver(II) perchlorate, shows a trigonal distortion of the AgS6 chromophore. The AgN4O2 octahedron of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) is distorted such that the N−Ag−N′ bond angles deviate slightly from 90° [88.2(2)°−91.8(2)°] whereas the O−Ag−N and O−Ag−O′ bond angles are 80.5(3)° and 161.0(7)°, respectively, which deviate significantly from their ideal angles of 90° and 180°, respectively. The molecular structures of the pyz ligand and the S2O8 2− anion agree well with those observed in other compounds.
elements.clean_text: Each Ag2+ cation is equatorially coordinated to four N-donor atoms from pyz ligands [Ag-N1a = 2.239(9), Ag-N1b = 2.230(7) (×2), and Ag-N2a = 2.253(9) Å] and two axial O-atoms from the S2O8 2- anion at much longer distances of 2.62(3) Å. Thus, each Ag(pyz)2O2 layer of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) is made up of corner-sharing axially elongated AgN4O2 octahedra. The Ag-N bond distances observed in Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) agree with those found in related systems, e.g., Ag(2,2'-bipy)2(NO3)2  and Ag(L 4)(NO3)2 (L = meso-5,5,7,12,12,14-hexamethyl-1,4,8,11-tetra-azacyclo-tetradecane). Another Ag2+ compound, (1,4,7,10,13,16-hexathiacyclooctadecane)silver(II) perchlorate, shows a trigonal distortion of the AgS6 chromophore. The AgN4O2 octahedron of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) is distorted such that the N-Ag-N' bond angles deviate slightly from 90° [88.2(2)°-91.8(2)°] whereas the O-Ag-N and O-Ag-O' bond angles are 80.5(3)° and 161.0(7)°, respectively, which deviate significantly from their ideal angles of 90° and 180°, respectively. The molecular structures of the pyz ligand and the S2O8 2- anion agree well with those observed in other compounds.

elements.content: Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) consists of 2D square nets (Figure a) in which AgN4O2 octahedra are linked through pyz bridges with Ag−pyz−Ag distances of 7.11(2) and 7.15(2) Å along the (−101) and (010) directions, respectively. These 2D nets pack approximately along the (201) direction and are linked by bridging S2O8 2− anions to form a 3D polymeric network (Figure b).
elements.clean_text: Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) consists of 2D square nets (Figure a) in which AgN4O2 octahedra are linked through pyz bridges with Ag-pyz-Ag distances of 7.11(2) and 7.15(2) Å along the (-101) and (010) directions, respectively. These 2D nets pack approximately along the (201) direction and are linked by bridging S2O8 2- anions to form a 3D polymeric network (Figure b).

elements.content: Crystal structure of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8): (a) 2D square sheet made up of Ag2+ ions and pyz ligands. (b) 3D network made up of [Ag(pyz)2]2+ sheets and (S2O8)2− ions with dashed lines indicating long Ag1−O1 bonds. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. Atoms correspond as follows: red = Ag, blue = N, black = C, yellow = O and green = S.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8): (a) 2D square sheet made up of Ag2+ ions and pyz ligands. (b) 3D network made up of [Ag(pyz)2]2+ sheets and (S2O8)2- ions with dashed lines indicating long Ag1-O1 bonds. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. Atoms correspond as follows: red = Ag, blue = N, black = C, yellow = O and green = S.

elements.content: Isofield and isothermal magnetization measurements were carried out for a polycrystalline sample of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) using vibrating sample magnetometry and pulsed-field techniques. Our results are shown in Figure a. The magnetic susceptibility χ vs T gradually increases as the temperature is lowered, reaching a broad maximum at T max = 49 K. The relatively high T max value suggests the presence of significant AFM interactions in each 2D square lattice of Ag2+ ions. A least-squares fit of 1/χ vs T in the region 150 ≤ T ≤ 300 K to a Curie−Weiss law led to g = 2.011(1) and θ = −66.8(1) K, which signifies a dominant AFM interaction between adjacent Ag2+ magnetic moments. To quantitatively extract the spin exchange coupling constant J 2D for the 2D square lattice, we performed a quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) simulation of χ vs T for H = JΣSi ·S i+1. As shown by the solid line in the main plot of Figure a, the simulation agrees very well with the experiment for 20 ≤ T ≤ 300 K with g = 2.0 and J 2D = 53 K (under the convention in which a positive spin exchange parameter implies AFM spin exchange). This J 2D value is consistent with the value 52.4 K calculated from the expression J = 1.07·T max for the 2D square-lattice Heisenberg antiferromagnet with T max = 49 K and S = 1/2. Note that J 2D for Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) is significantly greater than those reported for related Cu2+ polymers including [Cu(HF2)(pyz)2]BF4 and Cu(ClO4)2(pyz)2. The χ vs T data show no indication for 3D magnetic order down to 2 K. Pulsed field M(B) measurements made at 0.5 and 1.5 K (Inset of Figure a) show a concave curvature as B rises to 64 T, indicating an effective 2D spin dimensionality of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8). Using eq 2 of ref 11, we estimate the saturation field B c to be 160 T.
elements.clean_text: Isofield and isothermal magnetization measurements were carried out for a polycrystalline sample of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) using vibrating sample magnetometry and pulsed-field techniques. Our results are shown in Figure a. The magnetic susceptibility χ vs T gradually increases as the temperature is lowered, reaching a broad maximum at T max = 49 K. The relatively high T max value suggests the presence of significant AFM interactions in each 2D square lattice of Ag2+ ions. A least-squares fit of 1/χ vs T in the region 150 ≤ T ≤ 300 K to a Curie-Weiss law led to g = 2.011(1) and θ = -66.8(1) K, which signifies a dominant AFM interaction between adjacent Ag2+ magnetic moments. To quantitatively extract the spin exchange coupling constant J 2D for the 2D square lattice, we performed a quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) simulation of χ vs T for H = JΣSi ⋅S  i+1. As shown by the solid line in the main plot of Figure a, the simulation agrees very well with the experiment for 20 ≤ T ≤ 300 K with g = 2.0 and J 2D = 53 K (under the convention in which a positive spin exchange parameter implies AFM spin exchange). This J 2D value is consistent with the value 52.4 K calculated from the expression J = 1.07⋅T max for the 2D square-lattice Heisenberg antiferromagnet with T max = 49 K and S = 1/2. Note that J 2D for Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) is significantly greater than those reported for related Cu2+ polymers including [Cu(HF2)(pyz)2]BF4 and Cu(ClO4)2(pyz)2. The χ vs T data show no indication for 3D magnetic order down to 2 K. Pulsed field M(B) measurements made at 0.5 and 1.5 K (Inset of Figure a) show a concave curvature as B rises to 64 T, indicating an effective 2D spin dimensionality of Ag(pyz)2(S2O8). Using eq 2 of ref 11, we estimate the saturation field B c to be 160 T.

elements.content: (a) χ vs T (○) for polycrystalline Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) using a probe field of 0.1 T where the solid line () represents the result of the QMC simulation. Inset: Magnetization measured at 0.5, 1.5 (pulsed fields) and 2 K (SQUID). (b) T-evolution of the single muon precession frequency ν. Inset: Muon decay asymmetry A(t) measured at 1.7 (red) and 10 K (blue).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) χ vs T (○) for polycrystalline Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) using a probe field of 0.1 T where the solid line () represents the result of the QMC simulation. Inset: Magnetization measured at 0.5, 1.5 (pulsed fields) and 2 K (SQUID). (b) T-evolution of the single muon precession frequency ν. Inset: Muon decay asymmetry A(t) measured at 1.7 (red) and 10 K (blue).

elements.content: As discussed above, Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) consists of 2D square lattices of Ag2+ ions and is a 2D antiferromagnet. Note that 2D square lattices of Ag2+ ions are also present in the 2D ferromagnet Cs2AgF4. In the AgF4 layers of Cs2AgF4, however, the corner-sharing AgF6 octahedra are axially compressed [Ag−Feq = 2.291 (×4) Å and Ag−Fax = 2.129 (×2) Å], which is responsible for the ferromagnetic spin exchange between adjacent Ag2+ ions.In the CuO4 layers of the representative 2D antiferromagnet La2CuO4, the corner-sharing CuO6 octahedra are axially elongated with the Cu d x 2−y 2 orbital being magnetic. By analogy, it is expected that the magnetic orbital of each Ag2+ ion in Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) is the Ag d x 2−y 2 orbital, and so the spin exchange between adjacent Ag2+ ions is AFM. This expectation is borne out from our first principles DFT electronic band structure calculations for Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) (see section 4 of the ).
elements.clean_text: As discussed above, Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) consists of 2D square lattices of Ag2+ ions and is a 2D antiferromagnet. Note that 2D square lattices of Ag2+ ions are also present in the 2D ferromagnet Cs2AgF4. In the AgF4 layers of Cs2AgF4, however, the corner-sharing AgF6 octahedra are axially compressed [Ag-Feq = 2.291 (×4) Å and Ag-Fax = 2.129 (×2) Å], which is responsible for the ferromagnetic spin exchange between adjacent Ag2+ ions.In the CuO4 layers of the representative 2D antiferromagnet La2CuO4, the corner-sharing CuO6 octahedra are axially elongated with the Cu d x 2-y 2  orbital being magnetic. By analogy, it is expected that the magnetic orbital of each Ag2+ ion in Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) is the Ag d x 2-y 2  orbital, and so the spin exchange between adjacent Ag2+ ions is AFM. This expectation is borne out from our first principles DFT electronic band structure calculations for Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) (see section 4 of the ).

elements.content: Finally, we examine if 3D magnetic ordering takes place in Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) on the basis of zero-field (ZF) muon-spin relaxation (μ+SR) measurements. As shown in the inset of Figure b, the time dependence of the muon polarization, i.e., the muon decay asymmetry A(t), exhibits oscillations below ∼8 K, which indicates that Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) undergoes a transition to 3D magnetic order throughout its bulk.
elements.clean_text: Finally, we examine if 3D magnetic ordering takes place in Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) on the basis of zero-field (ZF) muon-spin relaxation (μ+SR) measurements. As shown in the inset of Figure b, the time dependence of the muon polarization, i.e., the muon decay asymmetry A(t), exhibits oscillations below ~8 K, which indicates that Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) undergoes a transition to 3D magnetic order throughout its bulk.

elements.content: The extracted frequency ν as a function of temperature is shown in Figure b. A power-law fit of the temperature dependence of ν leads to the 3D magnetic ordering temperature T N = 7.8(3) K. For T > 8 K, the observed A(t) spectra show Gaussian relaxation, which is characteristic of the muon ensemble experiencing a static, random array of local magnetic fields.
elements.clean_text: The extracted frequency ν as a function of temperature is shown in Figure b. A power-law fit of the temperature dependence of ν leads to the 3D magnetic ordering temperature T N = 7.8(3) K. For T > 8 K, the observed A(t) spectra show Gaussian relaxation, which is characteristic of the muon ensemble experiencing a static, random array of local magnetic fields.

elements.content: The low value of T N/J = 0.15 demonstrates that the interlayer interactions are very weak. With this measured value of T N/J we can use a standard expression for the 2D square lattice Heisenberg antiferromagnet to estimate that the magnetic correlation length at T N is ∼103 lattice spacings, showing that a very large correlated region of spins needs to form before three-dimensional order switches on, larger than is found in the prototypical 2D square lattice Heisenberg antiferromagnet Sr2CuO2Cl2.
elements.clean_text: The low value of T N/J = 0.15 demonstrates that the interlayer interactions are very weak. With this measured value of T N/J we can use a standard expression for the 2D square lattice Heisenberg antiferromagnet to estimate that the magnetic correlation length at T N is ~103 lattice spacings, showing that a very large correlated region of spins needs to form before three-dimensional order switches on, larger than is found in the prototypical 2D square lattice Heisenberg antiferromagnet Sr2CuO2Cl2.

elements.content: To summarize, Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) consists of 2D square nets of Ag2+ ions resulting from the corner-sharing of axially elongated AgN4O2 octahedra and, in accord with its structure, exhibits characteristic 2D antiferromagnetism. μ+SR measurements indicate that the material undergoes 3D magnetic ordering below 7.8(3) K, thus implying that there are weak interlayer spin exchange interactions as mediated by the bridging S2O8 2− ligands.
elements.clean_text: To summarize, Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) consists of 2D square nets of Ag2+ ions resulting from the corner-sharing of axially elongated AgN4O2 octahedra and, in accord with its structure, exhibits characteristic 2D antiferromagnetism. μ+SR measurements indicate that the material undergoes 3D magnetic ordering below 7.8(3) K, thus implying that there are weak interlayer spin exchange interactions as mediated by the bridging S2O8 2- ligands.

metadata.title: Characterization of the Antiferromagnetism in Ag(pyz)2(S2O8) (pyz = Pyrazine) with a Two-Dimensional Square Lattice of Ag2+ Ions
